    Sources of data

    We identified the 35 published full‐text studies (Aliaev 2010; Allan 2008; Aversa 2010a; Aversa 2010b; Aydin 1996; Behre 2012; Benkert 1979; Boyanov 2003; Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Carroll 1984; Chiang 2007; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Haren 2005; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Li 2013; Lincoff 2023; Lu 2003; Lunglmayr 1980; Maggi 2016; Merza 2006; Morales 2009; Paduch 2015; Reiter 1999; Schiavi 1997; Seftel 2004; Shabsigh 2004a; Spitzer 2012; Yucel 2017; Zhong 2013) and eight abstracts (Aversa 2009; Gilbert 1992; Gooren 2011; Hakobyan 2013; Hisasue 2015; Rao 2023; Roth 2011; Zhang 2012). Thirty‐nine trials were published in English, two in Mandarin (Li 2013; Lu 2003), one in German (Lunglmayr 1980), and one in Russian (Aliaev 2010). While we attempted to contact the corresponding authors of the included trials that provided author information including email addresses to obtain additional information on study methods and results, we received replies from only one author regarding three relevant studies for the review (Aversa 2009; Aversa 2010a; Aversa 2010b).

    Study design and settings

    Forty studies were parallel‐group RCTs and three had cross‐over designs (Aversa 2009; Carroll 1984; Schiavi 1997). Eighteen studies were conducted at a single center (Aliaev 2010; Allan 2008; Aversa 2009; Aversa 2010a; Aversa 2010b; Aydin 1996; Boyanov 2003; Brock 2016; Carroll 1984; Gilbert 1992; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Li 2013; Lu 2003; Reiter 1999; Schiavi 1997), and 16 were multicenter trials (Behre 2012; Benkert 1979; Buvat 2011; Chiang 2007; Hackett 2017; Hakobyan 2013; Legros 2009; Lincoff 2023; Maggi 2016; Morales 2009; Paduch 2015; Seftel 2004; Shabsigh 2004a; Snyder 2016; Yucel 2017; Zhong 2013). The remaining studies did not report whether the study was a single center or multicenter trial. Almost all trials were conducted in European and American countries. Others were conducted in Taiwan (Chiang 2007), Turkey (Yucel 2017), and China (Zhong 2013). Aliaev 2010 and Boyanov 2003 were reported as "open‐label". Six studies did not provide information regarding blinding (Aydin 1996; Li 2013; Lu 2003; Yucel 2017; Zhang 2012; Zhong 2013). The included studies were performed between 1981 and 2023.

    Participants

    The 43 studies included 11,419 randomized participants. Most studies enrolled middle‐aged (aged 40 years and over) participants with sexual dysfunction. Eleven studies included younger males, but the average age of each study participant was 40 years or older (Aliaev 2010; Brock 2016; Carroll 1984; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Maggi 2016; Paduch 2015; Seftel 2004; Shabsigh 2004a; Yucel 2017). Chiang 2007 included participants between 19 and 70, and did not present the average age. Nine studies did not define their inclusion criteria in terms of age (Aydin 1996; Gilbert 1992; Hakobyan 2013; Kunelius 2002; Li 2013; Lunglmayr 1980; Rao 2023; Reiter 1999; Zhong 2013).

    To define sexual dysfunction, most studies used the IIEF, AMS, and symptoms of hypogonadism, such as reported inability to achieve an erection sufficient for intercourse. Snyder 2016 used the Derogatis Inventory of Sexual Function ‐ Male to assess decreased libido. Twenty studies used low total testosterone as an inclusion criterion, and below 12 nmol/L was the most frequently used as a cut‐off value (Aliaev 2010; Aversa 2009; Aversa 2010a; Aversa 2010b; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Hakobyan 2013; Haren 2005; Ho 2012; Li 2013; Lincoff 2023; Maggi 2016; Merza 2006; Paduch 2015; Rao 2023; Roth 2011; Seftel 2004; Snyder 2016; Spitzer 2012; Yucel 2017; Zhang 2012). However, seven studies included participants with a testosterone level of 12 nmol/L (Allan 2008; Boyanov 2003; Gooren 2011; Hisasue 2015; Kunelius 2002; Reiter 1999; Shabsigh 2004a). Thirteen studies did not report their inclusion criteria regarding baseline testosterone levels (Aydin 1996; Behre 2012; Benkert 1979; Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Carroll 1984; Chiang 2007; Gilbert 1992; Lu 2003; Lunglmayr 1980; Morales 2009; Schiavi 1997; Zhang 2012). Free testosterone was also used in 10 studies (Aversa 2010a; Aversa 2010b; Chiang 2007; Giltay 2010; Hackett 2017; Hakobyan 2013; Haren 2005; Legros 2009; Li 2013; Spitzer 2012). In addition, SHBG (Kunelius 2002), dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) (Morales 2009; Reiter 1999), and free androgen index (Merza 2006) were used for participant selection in select studies.

    While eight studies included participants with metabolic syndrome or type 2 diabetes mellitus (Aversa 2009; Aversa 2010a; Aversa 2010b; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Rao 2023; Zhang 2012; Zhong 2013), four studies excluded participants with hypertension and/or type 2 diabetes mellitus (Haren 2005; Merza 2006; Reiter 1999; Yucel 2017). One study included participants with pre‐existing cardiovascular disease or an elevated cardiovascular risk (Lincoff 2023). The remaining studies did not address the presence or absence of metabolic syndrome components.

    Major exclusion criteria included hormone therapy (e.g. anabolic steroid injection), history of cancer, history of major diseases (e.g. New York Heart Association class III or above cardiac disease), elevated PSA, polycythemia, or an abnormal digital rectal examination (concern for prostate cancer).

    Intervention(s) and comparator(s)

    In most studies, testosterone was administered in one of three forms: oral administration, intramuscular injection, or gel.

    Twelve studies used testosterone in an oral form, most of which used testosterone undecanoate (TU, 80 mg: Li 2013, Zhang 2012; 120 mg: Aydin 1996; Benkert 1979; Boyanov 2003; Lu 2003; 160 mg: Haren 2005; Zhong 2013) at different dose levels. Legros 2009 had three intervention groups, each taking 80 mg, 160 mg, and 240 mg of testosterone. Lunglmayr 1980 used mesterolone 75 mg, and Reiter 1999 used DHEA 50 mg. Morales 2009 used both TU 160 mg and 100 mg DHEA as interventions.

    Twelve studies used intramuscular injection, most of which used TU 1000 mg (Aliaev 2010; Aversa 2009; Aversa 2010a; Aversa 2010b; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Rao 2023). Two studies used testosterone enanthate (TE) 200 mg instead of TU (Gilbert 1992; Schiavi 1997). Carroll 1984 used an injection containing four components: testosterone propionate 30 mg, testosterone phenylpropionate 60 mg, testosterone isocaproate 60 mg, and testosterone 100 mg.

    Sixteen studies used gel containing testosterone. Eight studies used 50 mg testosterone (5 g, 1% solution) (Behre 2012; Buvat 2011; Chiang 2007; Hakobyan 2013; Roth 2011; Shabsigh 2004a; Snyder 2016; Yucel 2017). Others used 1.67% testosterone (Lincoff 2023), 25 mg testosterone (2.5% solution) (Hisasue 2015), 60 mg testosterone (2% solution) (Paduch 2015), and 100 mg testosterone (10 g, 1% solution) (Spitzer 2012). Kunelius 2002 had three intervention groups, each taking 125 mg, 187.5 mg, and 250 mg dihydrotestosterone gel. Three studies applied dosage adjustment, which changes the amount of testosterone according to the patient's condition (Brock 2016: 60~120 mg testosterone 2% solution; Gooren 2011: 5~7.5 mg testosterone 1% solution; Maggi 2016: 30~120 mg testosterone).

    Two studies used 5 mg testosterone patches (Allan 2008; Merza 2006). The other two studies used more than one form of testosterone (Aversa 2010a; Seftel 2004). Aversa 2010a had two intervention groups; the first group intramuscularly injected 1000 mg of TU, and the second group added 80 mg of oral testosterone to intramuscular injection. Seftel 2004 had three intervention groups, each using 100 mg gel, 50 mg gel, and 24.4 mg patch.

    Five studies used PDE5I in combination with testosterone (Aliaev 2010; Buvat 2011; Hakobyan 2013; Li 2013; Lu 2003). Aliaev 2010 had two intervention groups: one used only TU 1000 mg intramuscular injection alone, and the other used intramuscular injection with PDE5I. Lu 2003 used a mixture of oral TU, PDE5I, and vitamin E (Vit E).

    Most studies used only an identical placebo as a comparator. On the other hand, four studies used PDE5I only as a comparator (Aliaev 2010; Li 2013; Zhang 2012; Zhong 2013). Others used a combination of PDE5I and Vit E (Lu 2003) and a combination of PDE5I and placebo (Buvat 2011; Hakobyan 2013; Shabsigh 2004a). Aydin 1996 used two comparators: trazodone 150 mg and placebo. Boyanov 2003 compared testosterone to no treatment.

    Comparisons

    Most studies compared the intervention to a matched placebo. Three studies compared testosterone to PDE5I (Shabsigh 2004a; Zhang 2012; Zhong 2013), and four studies compared testosterone with PDE5I to PDE5I (Buvat 2011; Hakobyan 2013; Li 2013; Lu 2003). Aliaev 2010 compared testosterone and testosterone with PDE5I to PDE5I.

    Outcomes

    Sixteen studies reported both erectile function and sexual quality of life (Aliaev 2010; Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Giltay 2010; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Legros 2009; Li 2013; Lu 2003; Morales 2009; Rao 2023; Reiter 1999; Shabsigh 2004a; Spitzer 2012; Yucel 2017). Eleven studies reported erectile function only (Allan 2008; Aydin 1996; Chiang 2007; Gilbert 1992; Hisasue 2015; Kunelius 2002; Maggi 2016; Paduch 2015; Roth 2011; Snyder 2016; Zhang 2012), and two studies reported sexual quality of life only (Aversa 2009; Haren 2005). Eight studies reported cardiovascular mortality as an outcome (Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Ho 2012; Paduch 2015; Yucel 2017). Nine studies did not report any primary outcomes (Aversa 2010b; Benkert 1979; Carroll 1984; Gooren 2011; Groti 2018; Lunglmayr 1980; Merza 2006; Schiavi 1997; Seftel 2004). One study reported cardiovascular mortality as a time‐to‐event outcome, but we were unable to use the data for meta‐analysis because the study is event‐driven (reported as cumulative incidence) (Lincoff 2023).

    Nineteen studies used different versions of the IIEF instrument to report erectile function (IIEF‐15: Allan 2008; Chiang 2007; Hakobyan 2013; Lu 2003; Shabsigh 2004a; IIEF‐5: Aliaev 2010; Boyanov 2003; Giltay 2010; Li 2013; Yucel 2017; Zhang 2012; Zhong 2013; IIEF‐EF: Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Hackett 2017; Maggi 2016; Morales 2009; Reiter 1999; modified IIEF: Kunelius 2002; not defined: Rao 2023). While Lincoff 2023 used IIEF‐5, we were also unable to use the data for meta‐analysis as the study was nested within the parent trial (inclusion of men with low libido only). Two studies used AMS (Behre 2012; Ho 2012), and five used other questionnaires (Sexual Health Inventory For Men: Hisasue 2015, Roth 2011; Derogatis Interview For Sexual Functioning Self‐Report: Legros 2009; Male Sexual Health Questionnaire ‐ Ejaculatory Dysfunction Short Form: Paduch 2015; question 4 of the Psychosexual Daily Questionnaire: Snyder 2016). Aversa 2010a used IIEF‐5 and the sexual domain of AMS, and Spitzer 2012 used three measurements: IIEF‐EF, IIEF‐15, and Male Sexual Health Questionnaire. Gilbert 1992 used a sexual questionnaire, and Aydin 1996 did not report measurement tools for erectile function.

    Ten studies used AMS to report sexual quality of life (Aliaev 2010; Aversa 2009; Aversa 2010a; Behre 2012; Giltay 2010; Ho 2012; Legros 2009; Morales 2009; Rao 2023; Yucel 2017), and six studies used the IIEF overall satisfaction domain (Brock 2016; Carroll 1984; Chiang 2007; Reiter 1999; Shabsigh 2004a; Spitzer 2012). Hackett 2017 and Kunelius 2002 used both the total AMS score and IIEF overall satisfaction domain. Five studies used other questionnaires (self‐rating: Benkert 1979; Partial Androgen Deficiency of Aging Men: Boyanov 2003; Lu 2003; Global Assessment Question: Hakobyan 2013; Androgen Deficiency of Aging Men: Haren 2005; Sexual Encounter Profile: Li 2013). Two studies did not report how to measure the sexual quality of life (Zhang 2012; Zhong 2013). While 24 studies reported the number of participants with treatment withdrawal due to adverse events (Allan 2008; Aversa 2010a; Aversa 2010b; Behre 2012; Benkert 1979; Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Chiang 2007; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Haren 2005; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Li 2013; Maggi 2016; Merza 2006; Morales 2009; Paduch 2015; Reiter 1999; Shabsigh 2004a; Spitzer 2012; Yucel 2017), 10 studies only reported cardiovascular mortality (Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Legros 2009; Maggi 2016; Paduch 2015; Snyder 2016). Nine and 14 studies reported lower urinary tract symptoms using IPSS (Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Chiang 2007; Hisasue 2015; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Paduch 2015; Yucel 2017) and prostate‐related events (Aliaev 2010; Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Chiang 2007; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Maggi 2016; Paduch 2015; Snyder 2016; Spitzer 2012), respectively.

    While three studies reported long‐term outcomes (later than 12 months; Allan 2008; Aversa 2009; Aversa 2010b), the remaining studies reported only short‐term outcomes (up to and including 12 months).

    Funding sources and conflicts of interest

    Twenty‐one studies reported funding sources. Six studies were supported by Bayer Pharma AG (Behre 2012; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012), and three studies were supported by Eli Lilly and Co. (Brock 2016; Maggi 2016; Paduch 2015). Ten studies received grants or study medication from other pharmaceutical companies (Allan 2008; Buvat 2011; Chiang 2007; Haren 2005; Legros 2009; Lincoff 2023; Merza 2006; Morales 2009; Seftel 2004; Shabsigh 2004a), and three studies received grants from the National Institutes of Health or an academic institution (Schiavi 1997; Snyder 2016; Spitzer 2012). Five studies declared potential conflicts of interest with pharmaceutical companies (Allan 2008; Buvat 2011; Haren 2005; Lincoff 2023; Snyder 2016).

    Excluded studies

    We excluded 72 studies (103 records) after evaluating the full‐text publications. Most of the excluded studies (50 studies) used the wrong participants and, most often, participants were recruited regardless of erectile dysfunction. Other reasons for exclusion were the recruitment of participants with specific diseases (Amiaz 2011; Atkinson 2010; Bakhshi 2000; Basaria 2010; Basaria 2013; Del Fabbro 2013; English 2000; Gregori 2021; NCT01377103; NCT02712944; NCT02803073; Park 2020a; Rastrelli 2018; Seidman 2001; Srinivas‐Shankar 2010), participants that were younger than defined in our inclusion/exclusion criteria (Brown 2000; Butrova 1971; Crawford 2003; Fernández‐García 2022; Frederiksen 2012; JPRN‐jRCT1071210006; NCT00433199; Pasiakos 2019), and participants with primary erectile dysfunction (Kwan 1983; Park 2003; Skakkebaek 1981). Nine studies used the wrong comparator; specifically, six compared different types of testosterone without another comparator (Carson 2016; Gonzalez 2021; Honig 2020; Khera 2016b; Lipshultz 2017; Shirai 2022), and two compared testosterone with PDE5I versus testosterone (Harikai 2018; Narukawa 2021). Wu 2020 used Chinese medicine as a comparator. Eight studies used an ineligible study design (non‐randomized study: Dudek 2020; Jung 2016; Kogan 2023; Nankin 1986; Yassin 2014; and others: Hackett 2019; Mok 2020; NCT00161304). Four studies used the wrong intervention, like a combination of testosterone and another active drug (Cho 2016; Fontenot 2014; Gomaa 2006; Park 2020b). One study was withdrawn (NCT05484167). Details of these excluded studies are presented in the Characteristics of excluded studies section.

    Studies awaiting classification and ongoing trials

    We found eight studies that are awaiting classification (NCT00163566; NCT00185198; NCT00254553; NCT00349362; NCT00504712; NCT00710827; NCT01092858; NCT01786473).

    We also found four potentially relevant ongoing trials (Ioakeimidis 2021; IRCT20181106041575N1; NCT03281187; Russo 2021).

    Further details of these studies are presented in the Characteristics of studies awaiting classification and Characteristics of ongoing studies sections.

    Risk of bias in included studies

    See the risk of bias tables within the Characteristics of included studies for further details and Figure 2.

    • Open in figure viewer
    Figure 2

    Risk of bias summary: review authors' judgments about each risk of bias item for each included study.

    Allocation

    Random sequence generation

    We rated 20 studies as at low risk of bias since each of them described an appropriate method for random sequence generation (Allan 2008; Aversa 2010a; Aversa 2010b; Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Haren 2005; Legros 2009; Li 2013; Lincoff 2023; Maggi 2016; Merza 2006; Morales 2009; Paduch 2015; Shabsigh 2004a; Snyder 2016; Spitzer 2012). The remaining studies were at an unclear risk of bias.

    Allocation concealment

    We rated 16 studies as at low risk of bias (Allan 2008; Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Giltay 2010; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Lincoff 2023; Maggi 2016; Morales 2009; Paduch 2015; Reiter 1999; Snyder 2016; Spitzer 2012). Each of them provided assurance that concealment of the allocation sequence was adequately performed. The remaining studies were at an unclear risk of bias.

    Blinding

    Performance bias

    We rated 18 studies at low risk of bias since they reported appropriate methods of blinding of study personnel (Allan 2008; Aversa 2010a; Aversa 2010b; Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Giltay 2010; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Lincoff 2023; Maggi 2016; Morales 2009; Paduch 2015; Seftel 2004; Snyder 2016; Spitzer 2012). We rated two studies at high risk of bias since they had an open‐label design (Aliaev 2010; Boyanov 2003). We rated the remaining studies as at unclear risk of bias.

    Detection bias

    We rated 19 studies at low risk of bias due to adequate blinding (Allan 2008; Aversa 2010a; Aversa 2010b; Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Carroll 1984; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Lincoff 2023; Maggi 2016; Morales 2009; Paduch 2015; Snyder 2016; Spitzer 2012). The same two open‐label studies were also rated at high risk of detection bias (Aliaev 2010; Boyanov 2003). The remaining studies were at unclear risk of bias.

    Incomplete outcome data

    • Erectile function: we judged 14 trials at low risk of bias (Aliaev 2010; Aydin 1996; Behre 2012; Boyanov 2003; Buvat 2011; Giltay 2010; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Li 2013; Schiavi 1997; Shabsigh 2004a; Yucel 2017), and nine trials at high risk of bias (Allan 2008; Benkert 1979; Carroll 1984; Chiang 2007; Gilbert 1992; Maggi 2016; Reiter 1999; Seftel 2004; Snyder 2016). The remaining studies were at an unclear risk of bias.

    • Sexual quality of life: we judged 13 trials at low risk of bias (Aliaev 2010; Behre 2012; Boyanov 2003; Buvat 2011; Giltay 2010; Hackett 2017; Haren 2005; Ho 2012; Legros 2009; Li 2013; Merza 2006; Shabsigh 2004a; Yucel 2017), and four trials at high risk of bias (Benkert 1979; Carroll 1984; Chiang 2007; Reiter 1999). The remaining studies were at an unclear risk of bias.

    • Cardiovascular mortality: we judged 11 trials at low risk of bias (Aversa 2010b; Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Legros 2009; Maggi 2016; Paduch 2015; Snyder 2016). The remaining studies were at an unclear risk of bias.

    • Treatment withdrawal due to adverse events: we judged 13 trials at an unclear risk of bias (Aversa 2009; Carroll 1984; Gilbert 1992; Gooren 2011; Hakobyan 2013; Lincoff 2023; Lu 2003; Lunglmayr 1980; Rao 2023; Roth 2011; Schiavi 1997; Seftel 2004; Zhang 2012). The remaining studies were at low risk of bias.

    • Prostate‐related events: we rated 16 trials at low risk of bias (Aliaev 2010; Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Chiang 2007; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Li 2013; Maggi 2016; Merza 2006; Snyder 2016; Spitzer 2012; Yucel 2017), and one study at a high risk of bias (Reiter 1999). The remaining trials were at an unclear risk of bias.

    • Lower urinary tract symptoms: we judged five studies at low risk bias (Behre 2012; Chiang 2007; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Snyder 2016), and one study at high risk of bias (Legros 2009). The remaining trials were at an unclear risk of bias.

    Selective reporting

    We judged nine studies at low risk of bias given that reporting corresponded with a prior written protocol (Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Giltay 2010; Legros 2009; Lincoff 2023; Morales 2009; Paduch 2015; Snyder 2016; Spitzer 2012). We rated the remaining trials at an unclear risk of bias, mainly due to lack of a published protocol.

    Other potential sources of bias

    We judged eight studies as having an unclear risk of bias since only abstracts were available (Aversa 2009; Gilbert 1992; Gooren 2011; Hakobyan 2013; Hisasue 2015; Rao 2023; Roth 2011; Zhang 2012). We rated one study at an unclear risk of bias due to unexplained discrepancies between two published articles (Chiang 2007). The remaining trials were at a low risk of bias.

    Effects of interventions

    See: Summary of findings 1 Testosterone compared to placebo in men with sexual dysfunction (short‐term: sensitivity analysis); Summary of findings 2 Testosterone compared to placebo in men with sexual dysfunction (long‐term); Summary of findings 3 Testosterone compared to PDE5I in men with sexual dysfunction (short‐term); Summary of findings 4 Testosterone as an add‐on to PDE5I compared to PDE5I alone in men with sexual dysfunction (short‐term)

    See summary of findings Table 1; summary of findings Table 2; summary of findings Table 3; summary of findings Table 4.

    Due to high clinical and methodological heterogeneity in the overall analysis comparing testosterone to placebo (short‐term), summary of findings Table 1 was based on the sensitivity analysis, which excluded studies at high or unclear risk of bias.

    We downgraded the certainty of evidence mostly due to study limitations and indirectness across all comparisons. In terms of indirectness, participants in the included studies may differ from those of interest in the review for the reasons below.

    • Age: including young participants under 40 years old (Aliaev 2010; Brock 2016; Carroll 1984; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Maggi 2016; Paduch 2015; Seftel 2004; Shabsigh 2004a; Yucel 2017), or no description of the age criteria (Aydin 1996; Gilbert 1992; Hakobyan 2013; Kunelius 2002; Li 2013; Lunglmayr 1980; Reiter 1999; Zhong 2013).

    • Baseline serum testosterone level: including participants with over 12 nmol/L testosterone (Allan 2008; Boyanov 2003; Gooren 2011; Hisasue 2015; Kunelius 2002; Reiter 1999; Shabsigh 2004a), or no description of testosterone criteria (Aydin 1996; Behre 2012; Benkert 1979; Brock 2016; Buvat 2011; Carroll 1984; Chiang 2007; Gilbert 1992; Lu 2003; Lunglmayr 1980; Morales 2009; Schiavi 1997; Zhang 2012).

    • Comorbidities, namely metabolic syndrome: only 14 studies reported their inclusion criteria related to metabolic syndrome (Aversa 2009; Aversa 2010a; Aversa 2010b; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Haren 2005; Lincoff 2023; Merza 2006; Rao 2023; Reiter 1999; Yucel 2017; Zhang 2012; Zhong 2013).

    1. Testosterone versus placebo (short‐term)

    1.1. Primary outcomes
    1.1.1. Erectile function

    Three RCTs with 792 participants (testosterone 476, placebo 316) reported short‐term erectile function using the AMS‐sexual domain (Behre 2012; Ho 2012; Legros 2009). Testosterone likely results in little to no difference in erectile function (MD ‐1.15, 95% CI ‐1.76 to ‐0.54; I² = 8%; moderate‐certainty evidence) (Analysis 1.1). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious indirectness (–1) due to the inclusion of younger men.

    Ten RCTs with 2223 participants (testosterone 1135, placebo 1088) reported erectile function using the IIEF‐EF (Brock 2016; Chiang 2007; Hackett 2017; Maggi 2016; Morales 2009; Reiter 1999; Snyder 2016) or IIEF‐5 (Chiang 2007; Giltay 2010; Li 2013; Yucel 2017) (Analysis 1.2). Pooling across these studies by converting data from IIEF‐5 to IIEF‐EF, testosterone may improve erectile function (MD 5.69, 95% CI ‐0.02 to 11.40; I² = 99%; low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.3). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious study limitations (‐1) and serious indirectness (‐1) due to the inclusion of younger participants. The observed heterogeneity was explained in the predefined sensitivity analysis that excluded studies at high risk of bias. Due to the resulting higher certainty of evidence, the sensitivity analysis became the basis of the summary of findings table (summary of findings Table 1).

    1.1.2. Sexual quality of life

    Six RCTs with 1092 participants (testosterone 622, placebo 470) reported sexual quality of life using overall AMS (Behre 2012; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Legros 2009; Morales 2009; Yucel 2017). Testosterone may result in little to no difference in sexual quality of life (MD ‐5.09, 95% CI ‐9.45 to ‐0.72; I² = 90%; low‐certainty evidence) (Analysis 1.4). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious study limitations (–1) and serious indirectness (‐1). The observed heterogeneity was explained in the predefined sensitivity analyses that excluded studies at high risk of bias. Due to the resulting higher certainty of evidence, this sensitivity analysis became the basis of the summary of findings table (summary of findings Table 1).

    In addition, four RCTs with 846 participants (testosterone 426, placebo 420) reported sexual quality of life using IIEF‐overall satisfaction (Brock 2016; Chiang 2007; Hackett 2017; Reiter 1999). Testosterone may result in little to no difference in sexual quality of life (MD 2.21, 95% CI ‐1.23 to 5.64; I² = 99%; low‐certainty evidence) (Analysis 1.5). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious study limitations (‐1) and serious indirectness (‐1). The observed heterogeneity was explained in the predefined sensitivity analysis that excluded studies at high risk of bias. Due to the resulting higher certainty of evidence, this sensitivity analysis became the basis of the summary of findings table (summary of findings Table 1).

    1.1.3. Cardiovascular mortality

    Ten RCTs with 3525 participants (testosterone 1860, placebo 1665) reported cardiovascular mortality (Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Legros 2009; Maggi 2016; Paduch 2015; Snyder 2016). Testosterone likely results in little to no difference in cardiovascular mortality (RR 0.83, 95% CI 0.21 to 3.26; I² = 0%; moderate‐certainty evidence); this corresponds to 0 cardiovascular mortality per 1000 men (95% CI 1 fewer to 4 more) (Analysis 1.6). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious indirectness (‐1). Publication bias was not strongly suspected.

    1.2. Secondary outcomes
    1.2.1. Treatment withdrawal due to adverse events

    Nineteen RCTs with 3340 participants (testosterone 1787, placebo 1553) reported treatment withdrawal due to adverse events (Aversa 2010a; Behre 2012; Benkert 1979; Brock 2016; Chiang 2007; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Haren 2005; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Li 2013; Maggi 2016; Merza 2006; Morales 2009; Paduch 2015; Reiter 1999; Yucel 2017). Testosterone may result in little to no difference in treatment withdrawal due to adverse events (RR 0.74, 95% CI 0.52 to 1.05; I² = 0%; low‐certainty evidence); this corresponds to 11 fewer treatment withdrawals due to adverse events per 1000 men (95% CI 20 fewer to 2 more) (Analysis 1.7). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious study limitations (–1) and serious indirectness (‐1); we did not downgrade further for inconsistency.

    Results of a predefined sensitivity analysis that excluded studies at high risk of bias yielded similar results with regard to the effect size but resulted in a higher certainty of evidence; therefore, this sensitivity analysis became the basis of the summary of findings table (summary of findings Table 1).

    1.2.2. Prostate‐related events

    Eleven RCTs with 3477 participants (testosterone 1812, placebo 1665) reported prostate‐related events (Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Chiang 2007; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Maggi 2016; Paduch 2015; Snyder 2016). Testosterone likely results in little to no difference in prostate‐related events (RR 1.65, 95% CI 1.08 to 2.51; I² = 0%; moderate‐certainty evidence); this corresponds to 12 more prostate‐related events per 1000 men (95% CI 2 more to 29 more) (Analysis 1.8). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious indirectness (‐1). Publication bias was not strongly suspected.

    1.2.3. Lower urinary tract symptoms

    Nine RCTs with 1644 participants (testosterone 882, placebo 762) reported lower urinary tract symptoms using IPSS (Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Chiang 2007; Hisasue 2015; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Paduch 2015; Yucel 2017). Testosterone may result in little to no difference in lower urinary tract symptoms (MD ‐0.62, 95% CI ‐1.51 to 0.27; I² = 63%; low‐certainty evidence) (Analysis 1.9). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious study limitations (–1) and serious indirectness (‐1); we did not downgrade further for inconsistency despite moderate heterogeneity, given that it is likely not clinically meaningful.

    Results of a predefined sensitivity analysis that excluded studies at high risk of bias yielded similar results with regard to the effect size but resulted in a higher certainty of evidence; therefore, this sensitivity analysis became the basis of the summary of findings table (summary of findings Table 1).

    1.3. Subgroup analysis
    1.3.1 Participant age (less than 65 years versus ≥ 65 years)

    • Erectile function: we found that only one RCT with participants aged ≥ 65 years reported erectile function assessed by the IIEF‐EF (MD 2.10, 95% CI 0.93 to 3.27) (Snyder 2016) (Analysis 1.10). Since no study reported the data for participants aged less than 65 years old, we were unable to perform the subgroup analysis.

    • Sexual quality of life: we were unable to perform the predefined subgroup analysis because there were no relevant data.

    • Cardiovascular mortality: Snyder 2016 only included participants aged ≥ 65 years (RR 0.33, 95% CI 0.01 to 8.16) (Analysis 1.11). Since no study reported the data for participants aged less than 65 years old, we were unable to perform the subgroup analysis.

    1.3.2 Baseline testosterone serum level (less than 8 nmol/L versus ≥ 8 nmol/L)

    • Erectile function: we found that only one RCT included participants with testosterone levels less than 8 nmol/L and reported erectile function assessed by the IIEF‐EF (MD 2.10, 95% CI 0.93 to 3.27) (Snyder 2016) (Analysis 1.10). Since no study reported data in participants with testosterone levels ≥ 8 nmol/L separately, we were unable to perform the subgroup analysis.

    • Sexual quality of life: we were unable to perform the predefined subgroup analysis because there were no relevant data.

    • Cardiovascular mortality: Snyder 2016 only included participants with testosterone levels less than 8 nmol/L (RR 0.33, 95% CI 0.01 to 8.16) (Analysis 1.11). Since no study reported data for participants with testosterone levels ≥ 8 nmol/L separately, we were unable to perform the subgroup analysis.

    1.3.3 The presence or absence of at least one metabolic syndrome component

    • Erectile function: Giltay 2010 and Hackett 2017 included participants with metabolic syndrome and Reiter 1999and Yucel 2017 included participants without metabolic syndrome. The effect on erectile function assessed by IIEF‐EF in participants with metabolic syndrome was an MD of 3.14 (95% CI 1.16 to 5.12) and the MD in the participants without metabolic syndrome was 16.06 (95% CI 6.42 to 25.70). The test of interaction was significant (P = 0.01, I2 = 84.9%) (Analysis 1.12).

    • Sexual quality of life: Hackett 2017and Yucel 2017 reported sexual quality of life assessed by total AMS score. The effect on sexual quality of life in participants with metabolic syndrome was an MD of ‐0.17 (95% CI ‐3.52 to 3.18) and the MD in participants without metabolic syndrome was ‐22.60 (95% CI ‐28.30 to ‐16.90). The test of interaction was significant (P < 0.00001, I2 = 97.7%) (Analysis 1.13). Additionally, Hackett 2017 and Reiter 1999 reported sexual quality of life assessed with the overall satisfaction domain of the IIEF. The effect on sexual quality of life in participants with metabolic syndrome was an MD of 0.07 (95% CI ‐0.77 to 0.91) and the MD in participants without metabolic syndrome was 6.88 (95% CI 6.33 to 7.43). The test of interaction was significant (P < 0.00001, I2 = 99.4%) (Analysis 1.14).

    • Cardiovascular mortality: three RCTs included participants with metabolic syndrome (Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017) (RR 0.21, 95% CI 0.01 to 5.10), but the remaining studies in the analysis included participants without any information regarding metabolic syndrome. Therefore, we were unable to perform the subgroup analysis (Analysis 1.15).

    1.4. Sensitivity analysis

    The high degree of heterogeneity in the primary analyses was explained in our predefined sensitivity analyses, which excluded studies at unclear or high risk bias. Since we have greater confidence in the results of these analyses, they provide the basis for our summary of findings tables for this comparison (summary of findings Table 1).

    1.4.1. Erectile function

    All three studies using the AMS‐sexual domain were rated as low risk of bias (Behre 2012; Ho 2012; Legros 2009); therefore, these results did not change (Analysis 1.1).

    Of all 11 studies, six were rated as low risk of bias in the analysis that used the IIEF‐5 or IIEF‐EF (MD 2.37, 95% CI 1.67 to 3.08; I² = 0%; 6 RCTs, 2016 participants; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.16) (Brock 2016; Giltay 2010; Hackett 2017; Maggi 2016; Morales 2009; Snyder 2016). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious indirectness (‐1) due to the inclusion of younger participants. The high degree of inconsistency observed in the main analysis was now absent; we therefore did not downgrade further. We were unable to assess this analysis for funnel plot asymmetry given the paucity of studies.

    1.4.2. Sexual quality of life

    Five of six studies assessing this outcome using the overall AMS were rated as low risk of bias (Behre 2012; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Legros 2009; Morales 2009). Based on this analysis, testosterone likely results in little or no difference in sexual quality of life (MD ‐2.31, 95% CI ‐3.63 to ‐1.00; I² = 0%; 5 RCTs, 1030 participants; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.17). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious indirectness (–1) due to the inclusion of younger participants.

    Only two studies were at low risk of bias when assessing IIEF‐overall satisfaction (MD 0.56, 95% CI ‐0.11 to 1.23; I² = 65%; 2 RCTs, 786 participants; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.18) (Brock 2016; Hackett 2017). Therefore, similarly, we found that testosterone likely results in little or no difference in sexual quality of life. We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious indirectness (‐1) due to the inclusion of younger participants.

    1.4.3. Cardiovascular mortality

    All 10 studies included in this analysis were rated as low risk of bias (Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Legros 2009; Maggi 2016; Paduch 2015; Snyder 2016); therefore this analysis did not change (Analysis 1.6).

    1.4.4. Treatment withdrawal due to adverse events

    Twelve RCTs of 19 included in the main analysis were rated as low risk of bias (Aversa 2010a; Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Giltay 2010; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Maggi 2016; Morales 2009; Paduch 2015). Based on this analysis, testosterone likely results in little or no difference in treatment withdrawal due to adverse events (RR 0.81, 95% CI 0.56 to 1.19; I² = 0%; 2966 participants; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.19); this corresponds to seven fewer treatment withdrawals due to adverse events per 1000 men (95% CI 16 fewer to 7 more). These results are similar to those in the main analysis (Analysis 1.7).

    1.4.5. Prostate‐related events

    Based on 10 RCTs at low risk of bias (among 11 overall), testosterone likely results in little or no difference in prostate‐related events (RR 1.65, 95% CI 1.08 to 2.51; I² = 0%; 3439 participants; moderate‐certainty evidence) (Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Groti 2018; Hackett 2017; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Maggi 2016; Paduch 2015; Snyder 2016); this corresponds to 13 more prostate‐related events per 1000 men (95% CI 2 more to 29 more). These results are identical to those in the main analysis (Analysis 1.8) since the excluded study did not contribute any events (Chiang 2007).

    1.4.6. Lower urinary tract symptoms

    Based on six RCTs (of nine) at low risk of bias, testosterone likely results in little or no difference in lower urinary tract symptoms (MD ‐0.37, 95% CI ‐1.39 to 0.64; I² = 66%; 1488 participants; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.21) (Behre 2012; Brock 2016; Ho 2012; Kunelius 2002; Legros 2009; Paduch 2015). These results are similar to those in the main analysis (Analysis 1.9).

    2. Testosterone versus placebo (long‐term)

    2.1. Primary outcomes
    2.1.1. Erectile function

    Only one RCT with 42 participants (testosterone 17, placebo 25) reported erectile function using the IIEF‐EF (Allan 2008). We are very uncertain about the effect of testosterone on erectile function (MD 4.20, 95% CI ‐2.03 to 10.43; very low‐certainty evidence) (Analysis 2.1). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious study limitations (‐1), serious indirectness (‐1), and very serious imprecision (‐2).

    2.1.2. Sexual quality of life

    The RCT did not compare testosterone versus placebo for sexual quality of life.

    2.1.3. Cardiovascular mortality

    The RCT did not compare testosterone versus placebo for cardiovascular mortality.

    2.2. Secondary outcomes
    2.2.1. Treatment withdrawal due to adverse events

    Two RCTs with 122 participants (testosterone 81, placebo 41) reported treatment withdrawal due to adverse events (Allan 2008; Aversa 2010b). We are very uncertain about the effect of testosterone on treatment withdrawal due to adverse events (RR 1.04, 95% CI 0.58 to 1.86; I² = 0%; very low‐certainty evidence); this corresponds to 13 more treatment withdrawals due to adverse events per 1000 men (95% CI 133 fewer to 273 more) (Analysis 2.2). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious study limitations (‐1), serious indirectness (‐1), and very serious imprecision (‐2).

    2.2.2. Prostate‐related events

    The RCT did not compare testosterone versus placebo for prostate‐related events.

    2.2.3. Lower urinary tract symptoms

    The RCT did not compare testosterone versus placebo for lower urinary tract symptoms.

    2.3. Subgroup analyses

    We were unable to perform any predefined secondary analyses because there were no relevant data (Allan 2008: men aged 55 years and over, testosterone less than 15 nmol/L, non‐obese participants).

    2.4. Sensitivity analyses

    We were unable to perform the predefined sensitivity analyses since all included studies had a similar risk of bias (high or unclear risk of bias).

    3. Testosterone versus PDE5I (short‐term)

    Only one RCT with 64 participants (testosterone 30, PDE5I 34) reported erectile function, sexual quality of life, and prostate‐related events in this comparison (Aliaev 2010).

    3.1. Primary outcomes
    3.1.1. Erectile function

    We are very uncertain about the effect of testosterone on erectile function assessed by IIEF‐5 (MD ‐3.40, 95% CI ‐5.47 to ‐1.33; very low‐certainty evidence) (Analysis 3.1). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious study limitations (‐1) and very serious imprecision (‐2).

    3.1.2. Sexual quality of life

    We are very uncertain about the effect of testosterone on sexual quality of life assessed by AMS (MD ‐3.82, 95% CI ‐6.85 to ‐0.79; very low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 3.2). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious study limitations (‐1) and very serious imprecision (‐2).

    3.1.3. Cardiovascular mortality

    The study did not compare testosterone versus PDE5I for cardiovascular mortality.

    3.2. Secondary outcomes
    3.2.1. Treatment withdrawal due to adverse events

    The study did not compare testosterone versus PDE5I for treatment withdrawal due to adverse events.

    3.2.2. Prostate‐related events

    There were no prostate‐related events in either study group (Analysis 3.3). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious study limitations (‐1) and very serious imprecision (‐2).

    3.2.3. Lower urinary tract symptoms

    The study did not compare testosterone versus PDE5I for lower urinary tract symptoms.

    3.3. Subgroup analyses

    We were unable to perform secondary analyses because there were no relevant data or too few data in the included study.

    3.4. Sensitivity analyses

    We were unable to perform the predefined sensitivity analyses since we only included a single trial.

    4. Testosterone as an add‐on to PDEI5I versus PDE5I alone (short‐term)

    4.1. Primary outcomes
    4.1.1. Erectile function

    Four RCTs with 430 participants (testosterone + PDE5I 215, PDE5I 215) reported erectile function using the IIEF‐EF (Buvat 2011; Spitzer 2012) or IIEF‐5 (Aliaev 2010; Zhong 2013) (Analysis 4.1). Testosterone as an add‐on to PDEI5I may result in little or no difference in erectile function (MD 2.79, 95% CI 1.25 to 4.33; I² = 12%; low‐certainty evidence) after converting data from IIEF‐5 to IIEF‐EF (Analysis 4.2). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious study limitations (‐1) and serious imprecision (‐1).

    4.1.2. Sexual quality of life

    Two RCTs with 282 participants (testosterone + PDE5I 141, PDE5I 141) reported sexual quality of life using IIEF‐overall satisfaction (Buvat 2011; Spitzer 2012). Testosterone as an add‐on to PDEI5I may result in little to no difference in sexual quality of life (MD 0.34, 95% CI ‐0.76 to 1.45; I² = 72%; low‐certainty evidence) (Analysis 4.3). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious inconsistency (‐1) and serious imprecision (‐1).

    Only one RCT with 64 participants (testosterone + PDE5I 30, PDE5I 34) reported sexual quality of life using AMS (Aliaev 2010). We are very uncertain about the effect of testosterone as an add‐on to PDEI5I on sexual quality of life (MD ‐5.32, 95% CI ‐8.48 to ‐2.16; very low‐certainty evidence) (Analysis 4.4). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious study limitations (‐1) and very serious imprecision (‐2).

    Based on the body of evidence from RCTs that provided evidence of higher certainty, there may be little to no difference in sexual quality of life (low‐certainty evidence).

    4.1.3. Cardiovascular mortality

    The RCTs did not compare testosterone as an add‐on to PDEI5I versus PDE5I for cardiovascular mortality.

    4.2. Secondary outcomes
    4.2.1. Treatment withdrawal due to adverse events

    Three RCTs with 388 participants (testosterone + PDE5I 196, PDE5I 192) reported treatment withdrawal due to adverse events (Buvat 2011; Shabsigh 2004a; Spitzer 2012). Testosterone as an add‐on to PDEI5I may result in little to no difference in treatment withdrawal due to adverse events (RR 1.26, 95% CI 0.32 to 4.91; I² = 31%; low‐certainty evidence); this corresponds to 11 more treatment withdrawals due to adverse events per 1000 men (95% CI 28 fewer to 163 more) (Analysis 4.5). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious study limitations (‐1) and serious imprecision (‐1).

    4.2.2. Prostate‐related events

    Three RCTs with 373 participants (testosterone + PDE5I 185, PDE5I 188) reported prostate‐related events (Aliaev 2010; Buvat 2011; Spitzer 2012). We are very uncertain about the effect of testosterone as an add‐on to PDEI5I on prostate‐related events (RR 6.83, 95% CI 0.84 to 55.37; I² = 0%; very low‐certainty evidence); there were no events in the control group (Analysis 4.6). We downgraded the certainty of evidence for serious indirectness (‐1) and very serious imprecision (‐2).

    4.2.3. Lower urinary tract symptoms

    The RCTs did not compare testosterone combination therapy with PDE5I versus PDE5I for lower urinary tract symptoms.

    4.3. Subgroup analysis
    4.3.1 Participant age (less than 65 years versus ≥ 65 years)

    We were unable to perform any predefined subgroup analysis because there were no relevant data.

    4.3.2 Baseline testosterone serum level (less than 8 nmol/L versus ≥ 8 nmol/L)

    We were unable to perform any predefined subgroup analysis because there were no relevant data.

    4.3.3 The presence or absence of at least one metabolic syndrome component

    • Erectile function: Zhong 2013 included participants with diabetes mellitus (MD 5.80, 95% CI 2.20 to 9.40) (Analysis 4.7). Since no study reported data for participants without metabolic syndrome, we were unable to perform the subgroup analysis.

    • Sexual quality of life and cardiovascular mortality: we were unable to perform any predefined subgroup analysis because there were no relevant data.

    4.4. Sensitivity analysis
    4.4.1. Erectile function

    Based on the studies rated as low risk of bias (Buvat 2011; Spitzer 2012), testosterone as an add‐on to PDEI5I likely results in little or no difference in erectile function (MD 2.37, 95% CI 0.65 to 4.10; I² = 0%; 2 RCTs, 282 participants); this finding is consistent with that of the main analysis (Analysis 4.1).

    4.4. 2. Sexual quality of life

    As all studies that reported sexual quality of life using IIEF‐overall satisfaction were rated as low risk of bias, this analysis did not materially differ from the analysis including all studies. In contrast, the study that reported sexual quality of life using AMS was rated as high or unclear risk of bias.

    4.4.3. Cardiovascular mortality

    The RCTs did not compare testosterone as an add‐on to PDEI5I versus PDE5I for cardiovascular mortality.

    Discussion

    Summary of main results

    We identified 43 studies that informed three comparisons, namely testosterone versus placebo, testosterone versus PDE5I, and testosterone as an add‐on to PDEI5I versus PDE5I alone.

    Testosterone versus placebo

    For the comparison of TRT versus placebo, in an analysis that combined data obtained with both the IIEF‐5 instrument and the IIEF‐EF, and included all studies including those with study limitations and short‐term follow‐up (up to 12 months), we found that TRT may improve erectile function. This analysis was notable for a high degree of heterogeneity (I² = 99%), prompting us to downgrade the certainty of evidence. Based on a predefined sensitivity analysis that excluded those studies with methodological limitations, the observed heterogeneity was markedly reduced (I² = 0%), as was the pooled effect size. Based on these findings, TRT likely has little to no effect on erectile dysfunction. Similarly, TRT likely has little to no effect on the two other primary outcomes of this review, sexual quality of life (moderate certainty of evidence) and cardiovascular mortality (moderate certainty of evidence). The same was true for the three secondary outcomes, treatment withdrawal due to adverse events (moderate certainty of evidence), prostate‐related events (moderate certainty of evidence), and LUTS (moderate certainty of evidence). Our ability to perform predefined subgroup analyses based on participant age, baseline testosterone level, and presence of indicators of metabolic syndrome was severely limited due to lack of data. Findings were suggestive of a potentially larger impact of testosterone on both erectile function and sexual quality of life in patients without metabolic syndrome compared to those with metabolic syndrome.

    Long‐term data (> 12 months' follow‐up) were limited, with a single eligible trial that only informed select outcomes. Based on our analyses, we are very uncertain how testosterone compares to placebo in regard to erectile function (very low certainty of evidence) and treatment withdrawal due to adverse events (very low certainty of evidence). For all other outcomes, we found no RCT data. No subgroup or sensitivity analyses could be conducted.

    Testosterone versus PDE5I

    Results for the comparison of TRT to PDE5I were limited to short‐term data (up to 12 months) and to two primary outcomes and a single secondary outcome. Based on these findings, we are very uncertain how effects on erectile function, sexual quality of life, and prostate‐related events compare. We found no data for any other outcomes and were unable to perform any secondary analyses.

    Testosterone as an add‐on to PDEI5I versus PDE5I

    Data were once again limited to short‐term outcomes (up to 12 months). We found that testosterone as an add‐on to PDEI5I may result in little to no difference in erectile function (low certainty of evidence) or sexual quality of life (low certainty of evidence). We found no RCT data to inform the outcome of cardiovascular mortality. There may be little to no difference in treatment withdrawal due to adverse events (low certainty of evidence) and we are very uncertain about how prostate‐related events are affected. We found no RCT data for the outcome of LUTS. We were unable to perform any pre‐planned subgroup analyses. A sensitivity analysis based on risk of bias could only be performed for the outcome of erectile function and yielded results similar to that of the main analysis.

    Overall completeness and applicability of evidence

    Both the United States Food and Drug Agency (FDA) and the European Union (EU) European Medicines Agency (EMA) limit the use of TRT to men with current medical conditions preventing the release of normal testosterone levels. Specifically, the FDA restricts the use of testosterone therapy drugs to those men who have an actual medical condition, such as a tumor or genetic disorder, restricting the body’s normal release of testosterone. The EMA’s decision also noted that testosterone levels naturally fall somewhat with age, and that restoration of these levels in healthy older men is not an authorized use of medicine in the EU (Morden 2019). Therefore, use of TRT in men without a defined cause for low testosterone levels is an off‐label indication. Nevertheless, major professional societies in andrology and endocrinology recommend testosterone in the treatment of erectile dysfunction and problems with libido arising from low testosterone levels in aging men without other medical causes of low testosterone (Burnett 2018; EAU 2023; Khera 2016a; Lunenfeld 2013; Mulhall 2018; Wang 2009). Our review would draw the evidence base for these recommendations into question.

    • We included many studies assessing the use of TRT in men with erectile dysfunction as presenting symptoms in the absence of a discernible organic etiology for low testosterone levels. We therefore believe that this evidence is broadly applicable to patients presenting with these erectile dysfunctions exploring the use of TRT. We included all approved formulations of testosterone overall (approximately a third of trials used topical gel, intramuscular, or oral formulations) but we did not explore how these compared. Based on their short‐acting pharmacokinetics, topical formulations are preferred. It has been suggested that testosterone injections may pose a greater risk of cardiovascular events due to spikes in serum testosterone levels (Dimopoulou 2016). However, given the lack of direct comparisons among different testosterone products, the evidence on the relative merits of different formulations remains inconclusive.

    • The inclusion criteria of the included studies differed by age or baseline testosterone (i.e. the definition of low testosterone differed between studies). Currently, available guidelines suggest that TRT may improve sexual function in aging men with low testosterone. However, testosterone deficiency combined with sexual symptoms may occur in a small minority of aging men (EAU 2023; Khera 2016a; Mulhall 2018). Given that the included studies in this review did not limit the participants to those in whom the deficiency has been confirmed by laboratory tests, our results appear applicable to people with sexual dysfunction regardless of their serum testosterone levels.

    • Few studies compared testosterone monotherapy or combination therapy to PDE5I, which is the current gold standard for the treatment of erectile dysfunction. Studies of the effects of TRT compared to current standard therapy would be of particular interest.

    • Two observational studies found that TRT may increase the risk of myocardial infarction (Finkle 2014; Vigen 2013). However, these findings were not confirmed by the evidence from RCTs. There are several risk factors, such as smoking, physical inactivity, and an unhealthy diet, which can increase the likelihood of developing cardiovascular disease. Therefore, further studies should address potential measured and unmeasured risk factors. Additionally, older people, who may be most affected by their already poor health (i.e. prior cardiovascular disease), are usually not considered as appropriate candidates in typical RCTs.

    • The existing body of evidence was limited to relatively short‐term outcomes (up to 12 months' follow‐up). In particular, this appears insufficient to provide assurance of long‐term cardiovascular risk. More high‐quality studies with long‐term follow‐up are needed to address these limitations.

    Quality of the evidence

    The certainty of evidence assessed using GRADE ranged from moderate to very low, indicating that we downgraded at least once for each outcome. The reasons for downgrading were as follows:

    • Whereas many included studies were at overall low risk of bias, a subset of studies had issues around unclear methods of randomization and allocation concealment (selection bias), unclear blinding of participants and personnel (performance bias) and unclear blinding of outcome assessors (detection bias), and unclear proportions of randomized participants included in the outcome analyses (attrition bias), as well as a lack of registered or published a priori protocol (selective reporting). These issues prompted us to downgrade for study limitations. When conducting the predefined sensitivity analyses when comparing testosterone to placebo, removing these studies increased the certainty of evidence.

    • We also downgraded for inconsistency, referring to (unexplained) heterogeneity of study results. In the main analysis for testosterone versus placebo, exclusion of the studies at unclear risk of bias (see above) resolved this issue entirely. We also downgraded for inconsistency in the testosterone as an add‐on to PDE5I versus PDE5I comparison.

    • Another reason for downgrading was imprecision due to small aggregate sample sizes (despite the pooling of two or more studies) and low event rates.

    • We also noted some degree of indirectness related to our PICO question (population, interventions, comparators, and outcomes) and the studies identified with regard to the participants; namely, several of the included studies involved participants under the age of 40 in whom erectile dysfunction may have had a different etiology.

    Potential biases in the review process

    This review was performed using standard Cochrane methodology and without any restrictions regarding the language or date of publication. Despite a comprehensive search strategy with no publication or language restrictions, we may have missed additional RCTs that may be unpublished or were published in languages other than English, or both.

    With the exception of the comparison of testosterone versus placebo, the small number of studies included in the review comparisons was insufficient to generate funnel plots; therefore, the risk of publication bias may have been underestimated. Additionally, some of the studies that were included in the qualitative analysis did not report any primary outcomes. Again, therefore, the risk of publication bias may have been underestimated.

    MCIDs for the AMS and overall satisfaction domain of the IIEF were not available from any published literature. The same goes for the other predefined outcomes and the proposed thresholds were based on the clinical experience of the review authors who have clinical expertise in urology (ECH, CKO, HSY, HWK, JHJ, and PD) and endocrinology (WT and JSL). We realize that using an alternative MCID level would lead to different interpretations (Hultcrantz 2017). However, interpretation of the analyzed results based on the IIEF‐EF and IIEF‐5 was based on established MCID thresholds.

    Agreements and disagreements with other studies or reviews

    The most comparable systematic review is the evidence report by Diem et al (Diem 2020), which included one of the authors of this review (PD) and helped to inform the American College of Physicians guidelines on TRT in adult men with age‐related low testosterone levels (Qaseem 2020). The guidelines made a recommendation for discussing the initiation of TRT in men with age‐related low testosterone levels wanting to improve sexual function (conditional recommendation for; low‐certainty evidence) and to re‐evaluate these men within 12 months (conditional recommendation for; low‐certainty evidence). While including many of the same RCTs, our review differs in the inclusion only of those studies in which participants presented with a baseline complaint of sexual dysfunction (although they may also have had other complaints). As a result, different studies were included in the analysis of the effect of TRT on erectile function, for which the authors reported a SMD of 0.27 (95% CI 0.09 to 0.44) based on seven trials from sensitivity analyses that excluded four trials rated as being at high risk of bias due to non‐placebo controls. This pooled body of evidence was rated as being of low certainty. The authors used Cohen's definition of 0.20 as the threshold for a small effect size, thereby concluding that TRT may improve sexual functioning and quality of life, although effect sizes were small. These findings correspond broadly to ours: as mentioned above, interpretation of this body of evidence is highly dependent on assumed thresholds of what represents the MCID. We used single thresholds, for example, an MCID of 5 for the IIEF‐5 based on a minimally contextualized GRADE approach (Zeng 2022), rather than several thresholds as one would in a more fully contextualized GRADE approach that distinguishes between effect sizes being trivial or none, small, moderate, or large (Schunemann 2022).

    A prior systematic review included RCTs with hypogonadal men (Ponce 2018). They included four trials and reported an effect on erectile function of a SMD of 0.16 (95% CI 0.06 to 0.27), which we would regard as trivial. The authors did not rate the certainty of evidence.

    Elliott 2017 reported a protocol‐driven systematic review with network meta‐analysis that also included non‐randomized trials, although these were not included in the quantitative analysis. Based on the pairwise comparisons of TRT versus placebo, they found a SMD of 0.25 (95% CI 0.10 to 0.412) in favor of TRT. Removing trials that included men with major comorbidities reduced heterogeneity and increased the effect size to a SMD of 0.36 (95% CI 0.21 to 0.51). The network meta‐analysis found no significant differences in erectile function between placebo and various forms of testosterone. The authors did not rate the certainty of evidence.

    Corona 2017 was an influential systematic review since it informed the chapter on hypogonadism in the European Association of Urology guideline on Sexual and Reproductive Health (EAU 2023). This systematic review lacked a protocol and included all placebo‐controlled trials in men investigating the effect of TRT, which, as for Diem 2020, led to the inclusion of overlapping, but also somewhat different bodies of evidence. In their primary analysis of 14 trials that reported outcomes using the IIEF‐ED or IIEF‐5, employing a fixed‐effect model, they reported a SMD of 0.32 (95% CI 0.28 to 0.41). The authors concluded that TRT significantly improves erectile function and other sexual parameters without further qualifying the effect size or rating the certainty of evidence. EAU 2023 currently makes a strong recommendation to use testosterone therapy as a first‐line therapy in patients with symptomatic hypogonadism and mild erectile dysfunction.

    Several older studies have raised concerns about an increased cardiovascular risk associated with TRT (Finkle 2014; US Food and Drug Administration; Vigen 2013). While Xu 2013 showed that TRT increased the risk of a cardiovascular‐related event (not mortality), recent systematic reviews did not confirm these findings based on an analysis of RCT evidence, similar to our findings (Ayele 2021; Diem 2020). Recently, a RCT with 5204 participants, included in this review, reported that in men with hypogonadism and pre‐existing cardiovascular disease or a high risk of cardiovascular disease, TRT was non‐inferior to placebo in terms of the incidence of major adverse cardiac events (hazard ratio 0.96, 95% CI 0.78 to 1.17) and cardiovascular mortality (hazard ratio 0.84, 95% CI 0.63 to 1.12) (Lincoff 2023). A large cohort study in men without a history of prevalent cardiovascular disease also found that TRT was not associated with an increased risk of incident cardiovascular events (Shores 2021). In addition, Ayele 2021 found that TRT may not be associated with venous thromboembolism compared with placebo (RR 1.03, 95% CI 0.49 to 2.14; I2 = 0%; low‐quality evidence), but qualified their results by stating that the estimates had wide 95% CIs, and a clinically important increased risk could not be ruled out. In our review, we found moderate‐certainty evidence of little to no effect but no long‐term evidence. Given that TRT therapy is often prescribed long‐term, this is an important limitation.

    In a systematic review that also included 14 RCTs and focused on LUTS, Kohn 2016 found little to no difference in International Prostatism Symptom Score (IPSS) among patients receiving TRT versus placebo.

    GRADE Working Group grades of evidence
    High certainty: we are very confident that the true effect lies close to that of the estimate of the effect.
    Moderate certainty: we are moderately confident in the effect estimate: the true effect is likely to be close to the estimate of the effect, but there is a possibility that it is substantially different.
    Low certainty: our confidence in the effect estimate is limited: the true effect may be substantially different from the estimate of the effect.
    Very low certainty: we have very little confidence in the effect estimate: the true effect is likely to be substantially different from the estimate of effect.
